newsitem.title: UK: Low commercial stocks boost metals - Rudolf Wolff.
newsitem.headline: Low commercial stocks boost metals - Rudolf Wolff.

text.p: Tight commercial stocks in copper and other base metals, some of them below critical levels, are a key factor driving markets higher, brokers Rudolf Wolff said in a report.
Total commercial stocks for copper equal just 3.8 weeks of consumption, compared to what the brokers consider the "critical level" of five weeks, the report said.
"With the exception of nickel, where stocks are above critical levels, the fundamentals suggest that supply deficits will lead significant stock shortages," it said.
Copper was expected to remain tight and "vulnerable to further price spikes over this quarter" on strength in underlying demand excerbated by low stocks, delays in start-ups and industrial disputes.
Later in the year, however, copper prices would ease as the market shifts into a supply surplus, it added.
Aluminium stock levels at 6.6 weeks' worth of consumption and zinc at 6.7 weeks are also drawing close to the six-week critical level.
"Strong economic growth...coupled with further anticipated deficit on top of this year's drawdown, should take total commerical stocks (of aluminium) down below critical levels," the report said.
"Zinc stocks are falling at a rate that will bring them down to cirical level before the year-end," it added. But increased producer and Chinese selling will dampen the rally as prices move higher.
Lead stocks are already below the 5.5-week point at 4.6 weeks, and is expected to stage a partial recovery this year, the report said.
Nickel stocks, however, are well above the seven-week critical point at 12.1 weeks. But demand for stainless steel is expected to rise.
Other bullish factors for some of the metals include strong world economic growth and investor interest in commodities.
